info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.

Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services availability based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Availability of emergency medical services by count
info.short_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

info.statement: There are {value} pediatricians in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)

Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as inadequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Intermediate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Intermediate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of intermediate. Intermediate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month, and the proportion of the number of visits is between 50-79%.   The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as intermediate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

info.short_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars.
info.long_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars. Based on the American Community Survey Table B19013 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: The median household income in {features.name} is {value} per year.

info.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
info.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
info.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community. Includes the employment accessibility indicator, the income inequality indicator, and the job participation indicator.
info.statement: The economic opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community. It includes the air quality indicator, the population churning indicator, the population density indicator, and the walkability indicator.
info.statement: The community environmental profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community. It includes the access to care indicator and the segregation indicator.
info.statement: The wellness disparity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community. It includes the affordability indicator, the education indicator, the food accessbility indicator, and the material deprevation indicator.
info.statement: The consumer opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community.
info.long_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community. It can range from zero (those with no formal schooling) to 20 (those with a doctorate/professional degree).
info.statement: The education indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community.
info.long_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community. Accessibility is determined by distance: close jobs are more accessible than jobs farther away.
info.statement: The employment accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community. It measures the proportion of the low income community that has a large grocery store within 1 mile in urban areas or 10 miles in rural areas.
info.statement: The food accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality.
info.long_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality, measures whether the income earned within a community is distributed broadly or concentrated within the hands of small number of households.
info.statement: The income inequality index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force.
info.long_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force. It includes both those currently working and those seeking work.
info.statement: The job participation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community.
info.long_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community. 4 indicators make up Towsend: overcrowding (>2 persons per room), unemployment, % of persons no vehicle or car, and % of person who rent.
info.statement: The material deprivation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The amount of population turnover within a community.
info.long_description: The amount of population turnover within a community. It measure the rate at which people both move into a community and move out of a community.
info.statement: The population churning index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.long_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.statement: The population density indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities.
info.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.
info.statement: The segregation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.
info.long_description: A measure of how walkable a community is based on residential and employment density, land use (destination) diversity, street connectivity and public transit accessibility.
info.statement: The walkability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation.
info.long_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation. This indicates how much income remains for other priorities, including food, health care and social activities.
info.statement: The affordability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk..
info.long_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk.
info.statement: The air quality indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care..
info.long_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care. It includes the proportion of uninsured residents and the number of physicians within 30 miles of the community.
info.statement: The access to care indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_name: Count of Households That Received SNAP
info.long_name: Count of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
info.short_description: The number of households in which at least one member received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months
info.long_description: The number of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as inadequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as intermediate in {features.name}.

info.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
info.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
info.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community. Includes the employment accessibility indicator, the income inequality indicator, and the job participation indicator.
info.statement: The economic opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community. It includes the air quality indicator, the population churning indicator, the population density indicator, and the walkability indicator.
info.statement: The community environmental profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community. It includes the access to care indicator and the segregation indicator.
info.statement: The wellness disparity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community. It includes the affordability indicator, the education indicator, the food accessbility indicator, and the material deprevation indicator.
info.statement: The consumer opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community.
info.long_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community. It can range from zero (those with no formal schooling) to 20 (those with a doctorate/professional degree).
info.statement: The education indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community.
info.long_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community. Accessibility is determined by distance: close jobs are more accessible than jobs farther away.
info.statement: The employment accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community. It measures the proportion of the low income community that has a large grocery store within 1 mile in urban areas or 10 miles in rural areas.
info.statement: The food accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality.
info.long_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality, measures whether the income earned within a community is distributed broadly or concentrated within the hands of small number of households.
info.statement: The income inequality index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force.
info.long_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force. It includes both those currently working and those seeking work.
info.statement: The job participation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community.
info.long_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community. 4 indicators make up Towsend: overcrowding (>2 persons per room), unemployment, % of persons no vehicle or car, and % of person who rent.
info.statement: The material deprivation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The amount of population turnover within a community.
info.long_description: The amount of population turnover within a community. It measure the rate at which people both move into a community and move out of a community.
info.statement: The population churning index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.long_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.statement: The population density indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities.
info.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.
info.statement: The segregation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.
info.long_description: A measure of how walkable a community is based on residential and employment density, land use (destination) diversity, street connectivity and public transit accessibility.
info.statement: The walkability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation.
info.long_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation. This indicates how much income remains for other priorities, including food, health care and social activities.
info.statement: The affordability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk..
info.long_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk.
info.statement: The air quality indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care..
info.long_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care. It includes the proportion of uninsured residents and the number of physicians within 30 miles of the community.
info.statement: The access to care indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_name: Count of Households That Received SNAP
info.long_name: Count of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
info.short_description: The number of households in which at least one member received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months
info.long_description: The number of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.
info.statement: The count of households that received SNAP in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_name: Percentage of Households That Received SNAP
info.long_name: Percentage of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
info.short_description: The percentage of households in which at least one member received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months
info.long_description: The percentage of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.
info.statement: The percentage of households that received SNAP in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.

info.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
info.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.

School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

info.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
info.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the percent of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_description: Mental health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). info.short_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: There are {value} dentists in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services availability based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as inadequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Intermediate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Intermediate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of intermediate. Intermediate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month, and the proportion of the number of visits is between 50-79%.   The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as intermediate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

info.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Adequate
info.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Adequate
info.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
info.statement: There are {value} cases rated as adequate in {features.name}.

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

info.short_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars.
info.long_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars. Based on the American Community Survey Table B19013 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: The median household income in {features.name} is {value} per year.

info.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
info.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
info.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the economic opportunities available within a community. Includes the employment accessibility indicator, the income inequality indicator, and the job participation indicator.
info.statement: The economic opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the natural, built and social environment of a community. It includes the air quality indicator, the population churning indicator, the population density indicator, and the walkability indicator.
info.statement: The community environmental profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community. It includes the access to care indicator and the segregation indicator.
info.statement: The wellness disparity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of the consumer resources available within a community. It includes the affordability indicator, the education indicator, the food accessbility indicator, and the material deprevation indicator.
info.statement: The consumer opportunity profile in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community.
info.long_description: The average number of years of schooling among adults in the community. It can range from zero (those with no formal schooling) to 20 (those with a doctorate/professional degree).
info.statement: The education indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community.
info.long_description: A measure of the number of jobs accessible to members of the community. Accessibility is determined by distance: close jobs are more accessible than jobs farther away.
info.statement: The employment accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community.
info.long_description: A measure of access to food by low income people within a community. It measures the proportion of the low income community that has a large grocery store within 1 mile in urban areas or 10 miles in rural areas.
info.statement: The food accessibility indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality.
info.long_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality, measures whether the income earned within a community is distributed broadly or concentrated within the hands of small number of households.
info.statement: The income inequality index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force.
info.long_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force. It includes both those currently working and those seeking work.
info.statement: The job participation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community.
info.long_description: Based on the Towsend Material Deprivation Index, it examines the private material resources available to households in a community. 4 indicators make up Towsend: overcrowding (>2 persons per room), unemployment, % of persons no vehicle or car, and % of person who rent.
info.statement: The material deprivation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The amount of population turnover within a community.
info.long_description: The amount of population turnover within a community. It measure the rate at which people both move into a community and move out of a community.
info.statement: The population churning index in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.long_description: A measure of population density that takes into account the density levels most people in the community experience.
info.statement: The population density indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities.
info.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.
info.statement: The segregation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.
info.long_description: A measure of how walkable a community is based on residential and employment density, land use (destination) diversity, street connectivity and public transit accessibility.
info.statement: The walkability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation.
info.long_description: The proportion of a community's income spent on housing and transportation. This indicates how much income remains for other priorities, including food, health care and social activities.
info.statement: The affordability indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk..
info.long_description: Includes EPA measures of pollution, including on-road, non-road and non-point pollution, and EPA measures of neurological, cancer and respiration risk.
info.statement: The air quality indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care..
info.long_description: Whether community members have access to a primary care physician and the means to pay for care. It includes the proportion of uninsured residents and the number of physicians within 30 miles of the community.
info.statement: The access to care indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_name: Count of Households That Received SNAP
info.long_name: Count of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
info.short_description: The number of households in which at least one member received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months
info.long_description: The number of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.
info.statement: The count of households that received SNAP in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_name: Percentage of Households That Received SNAP
info.long_name: Percentage of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
info.short_description: The percentage of households in which at least one member received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months
info.long_description: The percentage of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.
info.statement: The percentage of households that received SNAP in {features.name} is {value}.
